articles.headline: Jobs in Fighting Form After Liver Transplant
articles.snippet: A thin but energetic Steven P. Jobs reappeared at an Apple news conference and addressed his illness for the first time.
articles.abstract: A thin but energetic Steven P. Jobs reappeared at an Apple news conference and addressed his illness for the first time.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  After a prolonged absence from the public eye, a thin but energetic Steven P. Jobs reappeared Wednesday at an Apple news conference and addressed his illness in personal terms for the first time.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and David Pogue

articles.headline: U.S. Says Iran Could Expedite Nuclear Bomb
articles.snippet: Intelligence reports delivered to the White House say that Iran has created enough nuclear fuel to make a rapid sprint for a nuclear weapon.
articles.abstract: Intelligence reports delivered to the White House say that Iran has created enough nuclear fuel to make a rapid sprint for a nuclear weapon.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by William J. Broad, Mark Mazzetti and David E. Sanger and written by Mr. Sanger.

articles.headline: States Face Drop in Gambling Revenues
articles.snippet: As states expand gambling to stem budget shortfalls, the industry may be reaching a saturation point.
articles.abstract: As states expand gambling to stem budget shortfalls, the industry may be reaching a saturation point.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI  Casinos and lotteries in most states are reporting a downturn in revenue for the first time, resulting in a drop in the money collected by state and local governments, according to new state data.

articles.headline: Tech Ideas From Twitterland
articles.snippet: David Pogue’s followers on Twitter have a host of ideas for improving gadgets ranging from music players to laptops.
articles.abstract: David Pogue’s followers on Twitter have a host of ideas for improving gadgets ranging from music players to laptops.
articles.lead_paragraph: To make an electronics company, you need a lot of people: executives, managers, accountants, marketing, manufacturing, and on and on. But somewhere inside that cloud of administration, there are always a few anonymous geniuses, the heart of the company, the ones who keep the whole thing going: the people who actually come up with the ideas.

articles.headline: 100 Jobs? It Looks Good to Michigan
articles.snippet: In a state that has lost 800,000 manufacturing jobs this decade, old factories are being retooled to make renewable-energy products.
articles.abstract: In a state that has lost 800,000 manufacturing jobs this decade, old factories are being retooled to make renewable-energy products.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The announcement of a new plant employing just 100 workers might seem like a long shot to attract the chief executive of General Motors, two senators and a raft of state and local officeholders from across Michigan.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: In Florida, Vestiges of the Boom
articles.snippet: Only around 50 of the 396 units of the Tao Sawgrass condominium near Fort Lauderdale have been sold. Its backer, Corus Bancshares, is now tottering.
articles.abstract: Only around 50 of the 396 units of the Tao Sawgrass condominium near Fort Lauderdale have been sold. Its backer, Corus Bancshares, is now tottering.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the corner of Flamingo Road and Pink Flamingo Lane, beyond the putting green, the crystalline lagoon and the Sawgrass Mills mall, a soaring monument to the great condominium bust bakes under the Florida sun.

articles.headline: Obama, Armed With Details, Says Health Plan Is Necessary
articles.snippet: In blunt language before a rare joint session of Congress, the president presented his most forceful case yet for a sweeping health care overhaul.
articles.abstract: In blunt language before a rare joint session of Congress, the president presented his most forceful case yet for a sweeping health care overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama confronted a critical Congress and a skeptical nation on Wednesday, decrying the “scare tactics” of his opponents and presenting his most forceful case yet for a sweeping health care overhaul that has eluded Washington for generations.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Tech Companies Push to Digitize Patients’ Records
articles.snippet: Both large and small technology firms are devising ways to update health care records. About $19 billion in government financing will help.
articles.abstract: Both large and small technology firms are devising ways to update health care records. About $19 billion in government financing will help.
articles.lead_paragraph: On one proposal for health care reform at least, there is a rare bipartisan consensus: the push to computerize patient records.

articles.headline: Buy a G.M., Like It, or Get Your Money Back
articles.snippet: In an all-out effort to restore confidence in its products, General Motors will offer a 60-day, money-back guarantee on all its vehicles beginning on Monday.
articles.abstract: In an all-out effort to restore confidence in its products, General Motors will offer a 60-day, money-back guarantee on all its vehicles beginning on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Can a straight-talking Texan and a money-back guarantee persuade American consumers to buy a car from General Motors?
